national.notes: Nationwide resources are a starting point; always check your state’s specific laws, forms, and procedures.

florida.name: Florida

agencies.label: Florida Dept. of Revenue – Child Support

forms.label: Unmarried Fathers: Petition to Determine Paternity & Related Relief (Form 12.983a)
Married Parents: Petition for Dissolution w/ Minor Children (Form 12.901b1)

statutes: Best-interests standard; no gender preference; shared parental responsibility favored
florida.notes: Florida uses Parenting Plans and time-sharing (not ‘custody’). Courts apply the child’s best interests, encourage frequent and continuing contact with both parents, and (since 2023) start from a rebuttable presumption of equal time-sharing, subject to evidence.

infobox.title: How Florida Judges Decide & What Outcomes Look Like
factors: Each parent’s willingness to foster a close parent-child relationship and honor the schedule
Division of parental responsibilities; who actually handles day-to-day care
Putting the child’s needs ahead of one’s own
Stability and continuity of the child’s home/school/community
Moral fitness; mental & physical health of parents and child
Child’s school, home, and community record
Any evidence of abuse, neglect, domestic violence, or substance abuse

stats.label: Equal time-sharing (50/50)
stats.note: 2023 law adds a rebuttable presumption for 50/50 when appropriate.

stats.label: Sole custody to mother
stats.value: Still more frequent than to fathers
stats.note: But courts must apply gender-neutral analysis.

stats.label: Sole custody to father
stats.note: Typically requires showing mother is unfit or unable to care for child.

infobox.disclaimer: Percentages vary by county and judge; trends are high-level only.

wyoming.name: Wyoming

agencies.label: Wyoming State Bar – Find a Lawyer
University of Wyoming College of Law – Legal Clinics

forms.label: Custody & Child Support Modification Packet (Married or Unmarried)
Divorce with Children Packet – Married Parents

wyoming.notes: In Wyoming, both married and unmarried parents can use state-provided packets to file for custody, support, or modifications. Statutes are publicly available online via the Wyoming Legislature, with Title 20 covering Domestic Relations.

infobox.title: Custody in Wyoming: Key Factors & Outcomes
factors: Best interests of the child is the controlling factor (Wyo. Stat. §20-2-201)
Quality of each parent’s relationship with the child
Each parent’s ability to provide adequate care, education, and guidance
Stability and continuity of the child’s home environment
Child’s interaction and relationship with siblings and extended family
Willingness of each parent to respect the other’s rights and foster relationship
Any evidence of spousal or child abuse

stats.label: Equal/Shared custody (50/50 or close)
stats.note: Estimates: ~30–35% of cases result in near-equal parenting time.

stats.label: Primary custody to mother
stats.note: Nationally around 65–70% of sole/primary awards go to mothers; Wyoming similar.

stats.label: Primary custody to father
stats.note: Courts may award when mother is unfit, absent, or father is proven primary caregiver.

infobox.disclaimer: Exact percentages vary year by year and by judge. Stats shown are estimates from national and state-level studies.
